title: What are the best books on mathematical Numerical Analysis from a theoretical perspective? - Quora

response.answer_text: If by theoretical you mean mathematical, then the best one I have to recommend for an introduction to someone who already knows some analysis is An introduction to numerical analysis, by Endre Suli, who's a professor at Oxford.  I used it in my undergrad scientific computing class and eventually got to know others, but to me this remains the best I've encountered for a solid foundation on numerical analysis. It is clear and provides and proves all necessary theorems to develop a wide range of topics. The book is dense, but manageable even if you're not a math undergrad (as long as you know some analysis). If you are not much into proofs, another fairly good book that I keep right by my desk is Numerical mathematics and computing, by Kincaid and Cheney, both of which professors at UT Austin. I use this book as reference a lot. It provides several examples and pseudo-codes, as well as proof "sketches" of the most important theorems. This book can be read by anyone who's had single-variable calculus. If you are looking for a graduate-level mathematics textbook in numerical analysis, then I wouldn't know what to suggest, but at that level I believe it would be better to go after books on more specific topics (which is what I ended up doing).

I think it's pretty hard to declare a best book in a topic like numerical analysis.  No book is going to be comprehensive.  My advisor does research in numerical analysis.  In particular, finite element methods and splines.     This is her book of choice:   A Theoretical Introduction to Numerical Analysis: Victor S. Ryaben'kii, Semyon V. Tsynkov: 9781584886075: Amazon.com: Books  Personally, I've worked out of at least 4 books.  However, I've never read any of them cover to cover.  They are more applied books, however.   I'd be interested to see what others suggest.
